sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a status icon (&aka; tray icon) that informs you if you have new mail.
It works with system trays implementing the freedesktop.org System Tray Specification, such as the GNOME Panel Notification Area, the Xfce Notification Area and the KDE System Tray.

listitem.para: multiple mailbox support
Evolution, Gmail, &imap;, &maildir;, &mbox;, &mh;, &mozilla; products (Mozilla, SeaMonkey, Thunderbird, …), &pop3;, &sylpheed;, Windows Live Hotmail and Yahoo! Mail support
&sasl; authentication support
APOP authentication support
&ssl;/&tls; support
automatic detection of mailbox format
immediate notification (the status icon is updated immediately or within seconds after a mailbox changes)
message popups
HIG 2.0 compliance

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, it stays in the background and monitors the status of your mailboxes.
When new mail arrives, an icon similar to the following one is displayed in the notification area (&aka; system tray). The number of new messages is displayed over the icon.
Additionally:

listitem.para: if the Play a sound when new mail arrives setting is enabled, that sound is played
if the Enable message popups setting is enabled, information about each new message is popped up on your desktop

sect2.para: If an error is detected, the icon blinks.
Leaving your mouse over the icon will reveal more details about the status of your mailboxes. Clicking on the icon will perform the action specified in the Click Action setting.

sect1.para: The Mailbox Properties dialog is displayed when you add a new mailbox or when you edit an existing one. It may contain the following tabbed sections:

listitem.para: This is the type of the mailbox. If you select autodetect, the type will be autodetected using the mailbox &uri; and/or contents.

You can choose to assign a custom name to the mailbox. The mailbox name has informative purposes only, and is displayed in various parts of &app;. To reset to the default name, click on the Use Default button.

note.para: The mailbox name will be modified automatically as you set some of the other settings. To avoid losing your choice, only fill in the mailbox name after setting the other settings.

listitem.para:
This is the amount of time to wait between mail checks.
This delay is only used if the mailbox does not support immediate notification of changes.
This is the &uri; of the mailbox.

note.para: &app; abstracts file operations by using &gnomevfs;. All the schemes (http, ftp, sftp, …) supported by &gnomevfs; are therefore supported by &app;.

varlistentry.term: Account (Gmail, IMAP, POP3, Windows Live Hotmail and Yahoo! Mail only)

listitem.para:
This is the hostname or IP address of the &imap; or &pop3; server.
Symbolic names as well as IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are supported.
This is your username on the mail server.
This is your password on the mail server. If the password is filled in, it will be stored to your default keyring. If it is left out, a password prompt will appear when needed.

warning.title: IMAP and POP3 Security
warning.para: To avoid sending your password over the network in clear text, you must either use a SSL/TLS connection or select a secure authentication mechanism. See below for more details.

listitem.para: This is the &imap; mailbox to use.
This is the Evolution folder to monitor for changes.

note.para: For the folder selector to be available and for monitoring an Evolution mailbox, Evolution must be running and the Evolution Jean-Yves Lefort's Mail Notification plugin must be loaded.

listitem.para: This is the type of connection to use and the port number to connect to.
SSL/TLS on separate port refers to the most widespread method for establishing a &ssl;/&tls; connection: using a separate port.

note.para: The security considerations listed below do not apply if you select SSL/TLS (either in-band or on separate port).

listitem.para: This is the authentication mechanism to use. If you select autodetect, all the authentication mechanisms supported by the &imap; or &pop3; server will be tried, in descending order of security. Otherwise, the selected mechanism (and only the selected mechanism) will be used.

warning.title: Security
warning.para: If autodetect is selected and secure authentication fails, your credentials may be sent over the network in clear text (unless you use a &ssl;/&tls; connection).
If this is a concern, select the appropriate secure authentication mechanism from the drop-down list.

listitem.para: The IDLE extension (as defined by RFC 2177) allows &app; to stay connected to the server and provide immediate notification of changes.

If autodetect is selected, &app; will use the IDLE extension if the server supports it, unless the server software is known to have a broken IDLE implementation (currently, the only such software known to &app; is the University of Washington imapd). This is the recommended choice.

If always is selected, &app; will use the IDLE extension if the server supports it, regardless of the server software. Use this setting if you want to force &app; to use the IDLE extension, even if it has detected a bogus implementation.

sect1.title: Troubleshooting
sect1.para: If &app; does not work as expected, remember that you can obtain more details by leaving your mouse over its icon.

Additionally, a very efficient way to identify and solve problems is to run &app; using the --enable-info option and examine the output.
Security
The output of --enable-info may contain sensitive information such as passwords and session transcripts.

sect2.title: Immediate Notification
sect2.para: Immediate notification is the ability to detect changes to a mailbox without needing to check it periodically. It allows the status icon to be updated immediately (or within seconds) after a mailbox changes.
Requirements for immediate notification to be enabled:

listitem.para: &gnomevfs; must support monitoring (it usually does).
The &imap; server must support the IDLE extension, as defined by RFC 2177.
There is no requirement. Immediate notification is always enabled.

varlistentry.term: Gmail, &pop3;, Windows Live Hotmail and Yahoo! Mail mailboxes:

listitem.para: Immediate notification is not supported by these mailbox types.

note.para: If immediate notification cannot be enabled for a mailbox (either because that type of mailbox does not support it or because the requirements are not met), the mailbox will be checked periodically according to its Delay between mail checks setting.

question.para: How can I access the Properties dialog?

answer.para:
Choose
System Preferences Mail Notification (this location may vary across systems) or type mail-notification -p in a terminal.

question.para: You say that &app; supports <insert mailbox type or feature>, but there is no such entry in the Mailbox Properties dialog.

answer.para: &app; was built without support for <insert mailbox type or feature>.
If you have installed &app; from a package, contact the package maintainer and ask him to enable <insert mailbox type or feature> support.
If you have built &app; yourself, install the <insert mailbox type or feature> prerequisites (they are listed in the INSTALL file), then rebuild &app;.

question.para: I need &ssl;/&tls; for connecting to my &pop3; or &imap; server, but the &ssl;/&tls; settings are greyed out.
How can I monitor multiple &imap; folders?

answer.para: Add each folder as a separate &app; mailbox.

question.para: Can I monitor a <insert webmail provider> account?

answer.para: &app; has no native support for <insert webmail provider> mailboxes. However, &app; supports the &pop3; and &imap; protocols; you can therefore use a separate application for providing &pop3; or &imap; access to the <insert webmail provider> account.

question.para: How can I access message data from the new mail command?
I do not use &app; but I am presented with the properties dialog each time I log in. How can I disable it?

listitem.para:
Choose
System Preferences Sessions (this location may vary across systems).
Select the Startup Programs tab.
Uncheck the Mail Notification entry.

glossdef.para: A filesystem abstraction library allowing applications to access local, remote and virtual resources in a transparent fashion. GnomeVFS is part of the GNOME Desktop Environment.
A protocol allowing a client to access and manipulate electronic mail messages on a server. &app; implements version 4rev1 of the protocol, as defined by RFC 3501.
A mailbox format popularised by the qmail mail transfer agent. Messages are stored in a structure of directories for reliability.
The traditional UNIX mailbox format. Messages are stored in a single file.
A mailbox format popularised by the MH mail user agent. Messages are stored as separate files for flexibility and performance.

In this manual, a Mozilla mailbox refers to a mailbox produced by a Mozilla-based mail reader (Mozilla, SeaMonkey, Thunderbird, …). This mailbox format only differs from the &mbox; format by the fact that message status information is stored in the X-Mozilla-Status header instead of the Status header.
A protocol allowing a workstation to dynamically access a maildrop on a server host, as defined by RFC 1939.
A protocol securing a connection through the use of cryptographic techniques.
A method for adding authentication support to connection-based protocols, as defined by RFC 2222.
The mailbox format used by the Sylpheed mail user agent. The Sylpheed format adds a binary cache to MH folders for faster indexing.
A protocol securing a connection through the use of cryptographic techniques, as defined by RFC 2246. TLS is the successor of &ssl;.
A compact string of characters for identifying an abstract or physical resource, as defined by RFC 2396.
